Policy: Fresh Cut Flowers and Fresh Cut Greens Promotion and Information Act of 1993 (7 USC Ch. 97)
Policy_Content: This act provides for fresh cut flowers and fresh cut greens promotion and information. It states that Congress finds that (1) fresh cut flowers and fresh cut greens are an integral part of life in the United States, are enjoyed by millions of persons every year for a multitude of special purposes (especially important personal events), and contribute a natural and beautiful element to the human environment; (2)(A) cut flowers and cut greens are produced by many individual producers throughout the United States as well as in other countries, and are handled and marketed by thousands of small-sized and medium-sized businesses;  and (B) the production, handling, and marketing of cut flowers and cut greens constitute a key segment of the United States horticultural industry and thus a significant part of the overall agricultural economy of the United States; (3) handlers play a vital role in the marketing of cut flowers and cut greens in that handlers (A) purchase most of the cut flowers and cut greens marketed by producers; (B) prepare the cut flowers and cut greens for retail consumption; (C) serve as an intermediary between the source of the product and the retailer; (D) otherwise facilitate the entry of cut flowers and cut greens into the current of domestic commerce; and (E) add efficiencies to the market process that ensure the availability of a much greater variety of the product to retailers and consumers; (4) it is widely recognized that it is in the public interest and important to the agricultural economy of the United States to provide an adequate, steady supply of cut flowers and cut greens at reasonable prices to the consumers of the United States; (5)(A) cut flowers and cut greens move in interstate and foreign commerce; and (B) cut flowers and cut greens that do not move in interstate or foreign channels of commerce but only in intrastate commerce directly affect interstate commerce in cut flowers and cut greens; (6) the maintenance and expansion of markets in existence on December 14, 1993, and the development of new or improved markets or uses for cut flowers and cut greens, are needed to preserve and strengthen the economic viability of the domestic cut flowers and cut greens industry for the benefit of producers, handlers, retailers, and the entire floral industry; (7) generic programs of promotion and consumer information can be effective in maintaining and developing markets for cut flowers and cut greens, and have the advantage of equally enhancing the market position for all cut flowers and cut greens; (8) because cut flowers and cut greens producers are primarily agriculture-oriented rather than promotion-oriented, and because the floral marketing industry within the United States is comprised mainly of small-sized and medium-sized businesses, the development and implementation of an adequate and coordinated national program of generic promotion and consumer information necessary for the maintenance of markets in existence on December 14, 1993, and the development of new markets for cut flowers and cut greens have been prevented; (9) there exist established State and commodity-specific producer-funded programs of promotion and research that are valuable efforts to expand markets for domestic producers of cut flowers and cut greens and that will benefit from the promotion and consumer information program authorized by this chapter in that the program will enhance the market development efforts of the programs for domestic producers; (10) an effective and coordinated method for ensuring cooperative and collective action in providing for and financing a nationwide program of generic promotion and consumer information is needed to ensure that the cut flowers and cut greens industry will be able to provide, obtain, and implement programs of promotion and consumer information necessary to maintain, expand, and develop markets for cut flowers and cut greens; and (11) the most efficient method of financing such a nationwide program is to assess cut flowers and cut greens at the point at which the flowers and greens are sold by handlers into the retail market. It is the policy of Congress that it is in the public interest, and it is the purpose of this chapter, to authorize the establishment, through the exercise of the powers provided in this chapter, of an orderly procedure for the development and financing (through an adequate assessment on cut flowers and cut greens sold by handlers to retailers and related entities in the United States) of an effective and coordinated program of generic promotion, consumer information, and related research designed to strengthen the position of the cut flowers and cut greens industry in the marketplace and to maintain, develop, and expand markets for cut flowers and cut greens.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development, Cultivated plants
Keyword: Agricultural development,Business/industry/corporations,Financial agricultural measures,Consumer protection,Floriculture,Plant production,Education,Internal trade,International trade,Tax/levy
Geographical_area: Americas, Arctic, East Pacific, North America, North Atlantic

Policy: Sheep Promotion, Research, and Information Act of 1994 (7 USC Ch. 99)
Policy_Content: This act provides for sheep promotion, research, and information. It states that Congress finds that (1) sheep and sheep products are important goods; (2) the production of sheep and sheep products play a significant role in the economy of the United States in that sheep and sheep products are produced throughout the United States and used by millions of people throughout the United States and foreign countries; (3) sheep and sheep products must be high quality, readily available, handled properly, and marketed efficiently to ensure that consumers have an adequate supply of sheep products; (4) the maintenance and expansion of existing markets and development of new markets for sheep and sheep products are vital to the welfare of sheep producers and persons concerned with marketing, using, and producing sheep and sheep products, as well as to the general economy of the United States, and necessary to ensure the ready availability and efficient marketing of sheep and sheep products; (5) there exist established State organizations conducting sheep and sheep product promotion, research, and industry and consumer education programs that are invaluable to the efforts of promoting the consumption of sheep and sheep products; (6) the cooperative development, financing, and implementation of a coordinated national program of sheep and sheep product promotion, research, consumer information, education, and industry information are necessary to maintain and expand existing markets and develop new markets for sheep and sheep products; and (7) sheep and sheep products move in interstate and foreign commerce, and sheep and sheep products that do not move in such channels of commerce directly burden or affect interstate commerce in sheep and sheep products. It is the policy of Congress that it is in the public interest to authorize the establishment, through the exercise of the powers provided in this chapter, of an orderly procedure for developing, financing (through adequate assessments on sheep and sheep products produced or imported into the United States), and carrying out an effective, continuous, coordinated program of promotion, research, consumer information, education, and industry information designed to (1) strengthen the position of the sheep and sheep product industry in the marketplace; (2) maintain and expand existing domestic and foreign markets and uses for sheep and sheep products; and (3) develop new markets and uses for sheep and sheep products.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development, Livestock, Food & nutrition

Policy: National Water Policy 1994.
Policy_Content: This National Water Policy is a nationwide sectoral document aiming at promoting sustainable water resources development for (i) facilitating the equitable provision of adequate quantity and quality of water for all competing groups of users at acceptable costs and (ii) ensuring the security of supply under varying conditions. This entails establishing a well-defined institutional structure to achieve the intended policy objectives. The Policy follows a holistic approach to water management in which a comprehensive spectrum of demands are recognized and evaluated to assess their priority. Necessary measures and strategies to achieve long-term sustainability and effective management of the water resources are as follows (i) recognizing the important role of the water sector in the overall socio-economic development of the country; (ii) vesting ownership of water resources in the country under the State control; (iii) promoting water resources development through an integrated management approach; (iv) defining clear institutional responsibilities of all stakeholders in the sector; (v) developing an appropriate institutional and legal framework; (vi) promoting disaster preparedness to mitigate impacts of extreme occurrence of water such as flood and drought; (vii) recognizing water as an economic good.

Policy: Land Valuation Act (1994)
Policy_Content: This Act sets out the grounds of and procedure for the valuation of land. The results of a valuation are used in taxation, privatisation and land consolidation as well as in compensation for unlawfully expropriated land. The object of a valuation is a plot of land without the buildings, forest, other vegetation or accessories located thereon. In the event of an individual valuation, the object of the valuation may be a plot of land along with its essential parts and accessories. A valuation of land is based on the good practice and internationally recognised principles of valuation of immovables. The purpose of a valuation is to determine the usual value of land. The sales comparison approach, income approach, cost approach and combinations thereof are used upon valuation. The valuation of land is divided into mass valuation, individual valuation and valuation of unlawfully expropriated land.
Subject: Land & soil

Policy_Content: This Legislative Decree aims at land and environmental planning. The present Decree is composed of 20 articles. Article 1 deals with terms and definitions. Article 2 specifies the scope of this Decree. Article 3 defines requirements and conditions for the division of land. Article 4 decrees that the division of land or amendment of division should be adopted by the Ministry of Housing in accordance with provisions of this Decree and of its Implementing Regulations. Requirements and conditions for the division and planning of land shall be provided for in the Implementing Regulations (art. 5). Articles 6-8 pertain to application procedures and adoption. Article 9 decrees the ban on sale or rent of land before being adopted by the Minister of Housing. Articles 17-19 deal with complaints, offences and penalties.

Policy: Regional Act No. 8 on regional interventions to coordinate the agricultural development services and related research and experimentation.
Policy_Content: The Puglia Region promotes, programmes and coordinates on the regional territory the Agricultural Development Services and, moreover, encourages related research and experimentation activities, in compliance with the Regional Development Plan, the National Agricultural Plan and Regulation 270/79/EEC. Article 2 concerns the arrangement of the Agricultural Development Services, which shall pursue the following objectives: (a) encouragement of research and experimentation in the agricultural field and dissemination of results obtained; (b) promotion of formative programmes; (c) performance of demonstrations and arrangement of conferences with professional organizations, producers' associations, cooperatives and other agricultural associations, in order to orient agricultural production chooses, boost the technical and scientific modernization as well as culture innovation. Article 4 refers to the programmes and annual execution projects. Article 5 provides for the establishment of the Regional Committee for Agricultural Development (CoReSa) under the Regional Agricultural Counsel. The Committe shall elaborate proposals and submit advices for drawing up and enforcing the above-mentioned programmes and projects. In accordance with article 9, the Region encourages the creation of associations among agricultural entrepreneurs for the following purposes: (a) technical assistance to enterprises in matter of production processes compatible with the environmental protection; (b) introduction of alternative and innovative agricultural systems; (c) rational use of agricultural equipment. Agricultural technicians shall be registered in the Registry referred to in article 10, as per Regulation 270/79/EEC. Article 12 concerns research and experimentation.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development
Geographical_area: Alps, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries, Mediterranean, Southern Europe

Policy: Regional Act No. 8 laying down provisions in matter of soil protection and implementing Act No. 183 of 18 May 1989 and subsequent amendments.
Policy_Content: The present Regional Act aims at the conservation and protection of soil against all negative natural and anthropic agents, at the maintenance of water resources and at the ecosystem preservation, in compliance with the general principles laid down at the national level in Act No. 183 of 18 May 1989. Article 1 contains the list of basins of regional interest to be protected. Such basins are regrouped into the territorial areas defined by article 2. A Regional Basin Authority shall be set up for each territorial area. These Authorities shall govern the basins on an homogeneous basis and shall carry out related programming, planning and coordination activities (art. 3). Article 9 regulates, in particular, the content of the Basin Plans to be drafted and approved by the Regional Basin Authorities.
Subject: Land & soil, Water
Keyword: Soil conservation/soil improvement,Policy/planning,Institution,Basic legislation,River basin institution,Sustainable development

Policy: Decree of the Minister of Forestry No. 55/Kpts-II/1994 on the guidelines regarding the borrowing and use of forest zones.
Policy_Content: Borrowing and use of a forest zone is described in article 1(1) as the transfer of the use of part of the forest zone, both the ones which have been designated and the ones which have been determined, to another party for the purpose of development outside the forestry sector without changing the status, allotment and function of the said forest. Borrowing requires the approval of the Minister of Forestry (art. 2). Borrowing can be done against a compensation or without compensation. Borrowing without compensation can only be for a restricted public interest and for national defence purposes. Borrowing against a compensation can be done for commercial development purposes conducted by government agencies, state-owned enterprises, regionally-owned enterprises, cooperatives and private companies.
Subject: Forestry
Keyword: Public forest,Timber extraction/logging,Contract/agreement,Protected area,Forest management/forest conservation,Access right,Expropriation,Legal proceedings/administrative proceedings,Right of use

Policy: Geological and Mining Act.
Policy_Content: This Act, which is composed of eight Sections, lays down the general principles of: geological activities; extraction from deposits; protection of deposits, underground waters and other environmental elements affected by geological activities. The Act is composed of the following Sections: General provisions (sect. 1); Geological activities (sect. 2); Eextraction from deposits (sect. 3); Payments and fees (sect. 4); Neighbourhood relationship and liability for damages (sect. 5); Organs of the national administrations (sect. 6); Penalties (sect. 7); Final regulations (sect. 8).
Subject: Mineral resources
Geographical_area: Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries
Entry into force notes: The Act enters into force 6 months after its publication in the Journal of Laws.

Policy: Presidential Decree No. 236 of 1994 regarding the validation of the state strategy of environmental protection and sustainable development.
Policy_Content: The President decrees to validate the Main directions of the State strategy according to the Annex. The realisation of the State strategy is directed at the solution of the current socio-economic problems in strict connection with carrying out adequate measures for environmental protection and improvement of natural habitat, economy and restoration of natural resources. The document consists of 4 Chapters. Chapter I lays down the provisions for ecologically safe sustainable development under market economy. Chapter II deals with the protective measures as regards human natural habitat. Chapter III regards ecosystem recreation (restoration) in ecologically unfavourable areas. Chapter IV concerns Russian participation in the solution of global ecological problems.
Subject: Environment gen.
Geographical_area: Arctic, ASIA AND THE PACIFIC, Black Sea, Caspian Sea, CIS (Commonwealth of Independent States), Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, North Pacific, North-West Pacific
Entry into force notes: Entry into force on the date of signature.

Policy: Ley Nº 1 - Ley Forestal de la República de Panamá.
Policy_Content: La presente Ley tiene como finalidad la protección conservación, mejoramiento, acrecentamiento, educación, investigación, manejo y aprovechamiento racional de los recursos forestales de la República. El Instituto Nacional de Recursos Naturales Renovables (INRENARE), será el organismo que velará por el cumplimiento de esta Ley. Constituyen objetivos fundamentales del Estado las acciones orientadas a: 1) proteger, conservar e incrementar los recursos forestales existentes y promover su manejo y aprovechamiento racional y sostenible; 2) incorporar a la economía nacional las tierras patrimoniales del Estado de aptitud preferentemente forestal; 3) prevenir y controlar la erosión de los suelos; 4) proteger y manejar las cuencas hidrográficas, ordenar las vertientes y restaurar las laderas de las montañas; 5) incentivar y ejecutar proyectos de plantaciones forestales; 6) fomentar el establecimiento de bosques comunales; 7) fomentar la creación de organizaciones y empresas de producción, transformación y comercialización de productos forestales; 8) inventariar, estudiar e investigar los recursos forestales y sus productos; 9) educar; capacitar y crear conciencia sobre la importancia de los recursos forestales en todos los niveles de la población; 10) expedir la reglamentación actualizada sobre rozas y quemas en las zona rurales.
Subject: Forestry
Keyword: Forest management/forest conservation,Framework law,Forestry protection measures,Timber,Institution,Afforestation/reforestation,Timber extraction/logging,Erosion,Soil conservation/soil improvement,Public forest,Mountain area,Inventory,Land clearing,Traditional rights/customary rights,Community management,Special fund,Indigenous peoples

Policy: Law No. 4 of 1994 on Environment.
Policy_Content: This Law consisting of 65 articles divided in IV Parts and 10 Annexes aims at protecting the environment (land, air and water) from pollution. To achieve the objective the  Environmental Affairs Agency (EEAA) is established for the protection and promotion of the environment. Main tasks of the EEAA are: formulate the general policy and lay down plans for the protection and promotion of the environment and follow up their implementation; lay down a contingency plan to deal with environmental disasters; strengthen environmental relations between Egypt and other countries and regional and international organizations; prepare studies on the state of the environment; lay down the criteria to be observed before starting and during the operation of projects; lay down and follow up the rates necessary to ensure that permissible levels of pollutants are not exceeded; participate in the preparation and implementation of the national programme for environmental monitoring; publish periodic reports on the main environmental indicators; and prepare an annual report on the environmental situation to be submitted to the President of the Republic and the Cabinet. The Agency shall be managed by a Board of Directors chaired by the Minister of the Environment. It is also established in the Agency an Environment Protection Fund to the fulfilment of its objects.
Subject: Air & atmosphere, Environment gen., Land & soil, Sea, Water, Waste & hazardous substances

Policy_Content: Article 1 of the above-mentioned Agreement establishes that the Cantons of Basel-Landschaft and Basel-Stadt share a common Forestry Office bearing the official name of Forestry Office of both Basel Landschaft and Basel Stadt. The text – consisting of 10 articles – deals with the following matters: principles, applicable law, elections, functioning and competences of the Office and implementation of the Agreement.

Policy: Agreement on the Forestry Office for both Basel.
Policy_Content: Article 1 establishes that the Canton Basel-Stadt and the Canton Basel-Landschaft shall operate a Common Forestry Office for the performance of their duties. The common Forestry Office shall be nominated “Forestry Office of both Basel”. The text consists of 9 articles.

Policy: Regulation implementing the Federal Environment Act.
Policy_Content: The present Regulation lays down provisions concerning the organization and implementation of the Federal Environment Act of . In particular, it establishes the specific competences of the various entities dealing with the subject matter. The text consists of 38 articles divided into 3 chapters as follows: General provisions (1). This Part deals with purpose and sphere of application, general competences, the Environment Protection Office; Special provisions (2). This chapter concerns environmental assessment impact, publication of the environmental report, cases of special disturbance, cantonal police, substances harmful to the environment, waste disposal and waste from beverages packaging, harmful substances in the soil, air pollution, protection against noise. Final and transitional provisions (3).

Policy: Regional Act No. 5 on the interventions intended to restrict the use of chemical substances in agriculture and regulating organic farming.
Policy_Content: The Regional Act is divided into four Parts. It regulates the organic interventions intended for fighting cultivated plant pests and lays down provisions in matter of production, transformation and packaging of organic agricultural commodities. The main purposes are: a) restriction of the use of chemical substances in agriculture; b) maintenance of soil fertility; c) rational use of environmental resources; d) promotion of organic agricultural commodities quality. Part II of the Act makes provision on integrated, guided and organic fighting measures against pests. Within three months from the entry into force of the Act, the regional authority shall fix criteria for the elaboration of related programmes. The programmes shall be drawn up and enforced by: a) organic producers' associations; b) agricultural cooperatives; c) agricultural producers' consortia. Article 5 concerns the allocation of financial resources by the Region. Part III lays down rules in matter of organic production methods. Organic producers' associations shall be recognized by the regional authority when they fulfill all the requirements listed out in articles 9 and 10. Such associations must keep an up-to-date register on the associated enterprises. Article 12 regulates the withdrawal of the recognition. Inspections on processing methods shall be carried out by recognized associations and by the Region. Article 20 sets out penalties.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development, Food & nutrition, Livestock, Cultivated plants

Policy: Agricultural Cooperative Societies Proclamation No. 85/1994.
Policy_Content: A society established under this Proclamation shall have as objectives: (1) to improve the living conditions of its members; (2) to promote self-reliance among members; (3) to solve problems collectively; (4) to obtain modern technologies for its members; (5) to process agricultural products; (6) to promote teaching and training for its members (sect. 3). Provisions of Part II, concerning the formation and registration of societies, distinguish between a Primary Society and a Higher Level Society. A Primary Society shall be established on a voluntary basis by not less than ten peasants living in a given area (sect. 5). A Higher Level Society is a union or federation of Primary Societies (sects. 6-8). The field or area in which a Society may engage shall be determined in its By-laws (sect. 7). Any society shall be registered by the appropriate authority (sect. 9). Provisions of Part III describe the rights and duties of Societies and its members. Other provisions of this Proclamation deal with internal procedures, special privileges of societies, funds and properties as well as the winding up of societies. The Proclamation consists of 48 sections and which are divided into 8 Parts.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development
Geographical_area: Africa, AFRICA FAO, Eastern Africa, Landlocked Developing Countries, Least Developed Countries, Sahel

Policy: Decision No. 36 on professional licensing for managing forests and pastures.
Policy_Content: The Decision defines the authority of the General Department of Forests and Pastures, under the Ministry of Agriculture and Food, to create a commission to issue professional licences in the field of study, planning and implementation of different activities in forest and pasture management. Professional licences may be issued by the Agricultural Departments in cooperation with the Forestry Service Department, in accordance with regulations issued by the Professional Licence Commission. The General Department must compile, in cooperation with respective ministries, the regulations for issuing professional licences and instructions for the organization, duties and rights of the Commission. The regulations and instructions must be approved by the Ministry of Agriculture and Food.
Subject: Forestry
Geographical_area: Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, Mediterranean, Southern Europe
Entry into force notes: This Decision enters into force immediately.

Policy: Décret nº 94-265 portant création d'un périmètre public irrigué à Sidi-Shill - Sidi Ali J'Bini.
Policy_Content: Ce décret porte création d'un périmètre public irrigué à Sidi-Shill - Sidi Ali J'Bini. Il fixe à 60 ha la limite de la superficie totale des parcelles appartenant à un même propriétaire. La contribution aux investissememnts publics effectués dans ce périmètre est fixée à 600 dinars par hectare irrigable. Le périmètre est classé dans les zones d'interdictions prévues par l'article 4 de la loi nº 83-87 relative à la protection des terres agricoles.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development, Land & soil, Water
Geographical_area: Africa, Mediterranean, NEAR EAST AND NORTH AFRICA, Northern Africa

Policy: Act No. 97 on mountain areas.
Policy_Content: This Act is designed for the protection and the redevelopment of mountain areas in implementation of article 44 of the Constitution. The Act institutes the National Mountain Fund, at the Ministry of the Budget and Economic Planning. The resources of the Fund come from Community, central government and public entity transfers and are entered in a separate chapter in the budget of the Ministry of the Budget and Economic Planning. The Act vests mountain organizations established to manage agricultural and pastoral resources with legal personality under private law, and recognises the right of these organizations to draft their own Articles of Association. In the mountain communities, persons inheriting leases may acquire ownership of the leased land when the lease expires. In order to acquire ownership, the heirs must notify the coheirs within six months of the expiry date of the lease by registered post and recorded delivery of their declaration of acquisition, and within three months of service they must effect payment. The Act also provides that mountain communities may, individually or in association with others, and within their own territory, encourage the management of their forests under contracts between proprietors.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development
Keyword: Agricultural development,Less favoured areas,Mountain area,Special fund
Geographical_area: Alps, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries, Mediterranean, Southern Europe

Policy: Provisions of the State Council concerning imposition of agricultural tax on agricultural speciality income.
Policy_Content: With a view to rationalizion and adjustment of income from production of agriculture, forestry, animal husbandry and fishery, and to promote the development of agricultural production, these Provisions regulate the imposition of agricultural tax on agricultural speciality income. The following agricultural speciality product income shall be subject to agricultural speciality tax: (a) tobacco; (b) horticultural income (inter alia, fruit, dry fruit, rough tea, flowers and plants, etc.); (c) aquatic product income (e.g., mariculture and freshwater aquaculture); (d) livestock income; (e) forest income; (f) edible mushroom income; (g) other agricultural speciality product income prescribed by provinces, autonomous regions and municipalities under the Central Government. The national items and rates for agricultural speciality tax must adhere to the Agricultural Speciality Tax Schedule of Taxable Items and Tax Rates contained in the Appendix. Further provisions concern the collection and calculation of the tax and the circumstances where the tax shall be reduced or exempted. Agricultural speciality tax shall be calculated and collected according to these Provisions from the taxation year of 1994 (art. 14.).
Subject: Agricultural & rural development
Geographical_area: Asia, ASIA AND THE PACIFIC, East Asian Seas, Eastern Asia, North Pacific, North-West Pacific
Entry into force notes: These Provisions shall come into force on the date of promulgation (30 January 1994).

Policy_Content: The Chief of the Department of the Protection of Soil and Land Resources orders to the subordinate divisions of the Department and territorial branches of the Ministry to follow directions of the Regulation on the modalities of carrying out state control over the use and the protection of land. The Chief of the Department of the Protection of Soil and Land Resources orders to validate the list of the officials authorized to carry out state control over the use and the protection of land that are authorized to examine independently the cases of the infringement of land legislation. Territorial (local) branches of the Ministry must brisk up the work of interpretation of land and environmental legislation currently in force regarding the rational use and the protection of land, compensation for damages, make answerable the culprits in the process of the formation of land relations of new type based on private property on land.

Policy: Law No. 11.405 establishing the State Policy for Agricultural Development.
Policy_Content: This Law, consisting of 95 articles divided into five Chapters, defines the principles and objectives, actions and instruments of State Policy for Agricultural Development. It establishes institutional competencies and provides resources for the development of agricultural activity in the State. The objectives of this State Policy are: define and control actions and instruments to meet the needs of the agricultural sector, with a view to ensuring an increase in agricultural production, domestic supply, especially food, price and market stability, reduction of regional and income disparities and improvement of the living conditions of the rural family; promote cooperative initiatives of producers and rural workers; improve performance of socio-economic functions of agriculture; protect the environment, ensuring the rational use of natural resources and stimulate the recovery of degraded ecosystems; promote the creation of strategic stocks and standards, to establish better conditions for product marketing, supply and exports; provide institutional support to rural producers, prioritizing small producers, as well as the beneficiaries of agrarian reform programmes; promote the integration of agricultural programmes, providing rural families with infrastructures and services of health, education, sanitation, security, transportation, etc.; stimulate the process of agro-industrialization, including the manufacturing and other phases of the production chain; promote development of public and private agricultural technologies; ensure the regularity of the food supply, through a growing and sustained supply of basic products.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development, Livestock, Fisheries, Forestry, Water

Policy: Law No. 1.117 establishing the Policy on Environment.
Policy_Content: This Law, consisting of 148 articles divided into five Titles, establishes the Basic Policy on Environment of the State of Acre. It establishes the basic norms for the protection, conservation and preservation of natural environment and natural resources in order to improve and protect the quality of human mankind. The following fundamental principles will be observed for the implementation and monitoring of the Environmental Policy of the State of Acre: the life of the human being as the basis of environmental issues; the search for a guarantee of the quality of life of the populations without compromising the standard of living of future generations; minimize the environmental impacts of productive environmental activities; conservation and/or preservation of life support systems and biodiversity, in areas considered critical for their existence, based on technical and scientific studies; scientific and technological research directed to the sustainable management of natural resources; multidisciplinary approach to environmental issues; unity and continuity of environmental policy and management in time and space, without prejudice to the decentralization of actions.

Policy: Decree No.77 of 1994 of the Government of Moscow “On the proceedings of the registration of land tenants and ensuring the collection of land charges".
Policy_Content: The Government of Moscow, for the purpose of more efficient use of land, decrees to consider proceedings of the registration and inventory of land tenants a priority issue for the city of Moscow. The Government of Moscow decrees to entitle the prefectures of administrative districts and managing bodies to render Moscow land committee assistance in carrying out the set task. The Government of Moscow decrees to validate the Regulations on elaboration and legalization of ordinances of the prefects of administrative districts regarding the ascertainment of the right of land ownership in the process of the registration of land tenants (Annex 1) and the Program of planning and prospecting work for the purpose of ensuring the realization of land reform (Annex 2). The Regulations are carried into force for the purpose of regulating the procedure and shortening of terms of the registration of land tenants. Land registration on the grounds of the use of city land is carried out in four stages: I stage is data collection regarding the plot of land and the formation of land surveying file; II stage is the ascertainment of the right of land ownership by the ordinance of the prefect of administrative district; III stage is the legalization of the right of land ownership by means of official registration and issuing by Moscow land committee of the contract on lease or the certificate of state registration of land; IV stage is the entry into the City land register. After the conclusion of the IVth stage citizens and juridical persons are recognized by the state the right of ownership to the plots of land and the legality of land transactions as determined by the acquired right. All the land transactions become valid after the corresponding entry into the City land register that is kept and is in custody at Moscow land committee.
Subject: Land & soil
Geographical_area: Arctic, ASIA AND THE PACIFIC, Black Sea, Caspian Sea, CIS (Commonwealth of Independent States), Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, North Pacific, North-West Pacific

Policy_Content: The present Law lays down provisions relating to forestry administration contributions on behalf of municipalities and other bodies of public law. In particular, article 1 establishes that the costs for forestry administration in Baden Württemberg shall be incumbent to the Land. The text consists of 4 articles.

Policy: National Disaster Act 1993 (No. 12 of 1993).
Policy_Content: The principal object of this Act is to provide for the organization and management of response to disasters such as natural disasters and some man-made disasters as defined in section 2. Part II of the Act deals with the organization and management necessary for the co-ordination of activities of Government and non-Government agencies relating to disaster mitigation, preparedness, response and recovery. The Minister is given the overall general responsibility for such disaster relief (sect. 4), advised by the National Disaster Council (sect. 5). This Council is also given certain responsibilities for example the preparation and formulation of the National Disaster Plan (sect. 12), establishment of the Central operations group (sect. 7) and the determination of the responsibilities of the National Disaster Management Office (sect. 9). Part III of the Act deals with the National Disaster Plan and its formulation (sect. 12), periodic review and update of the Plan and activities by public and private agencies and local authorities (sects. 14 to 16). Part IV of the Act deals with the declaration of a state of public emergency by the Beretitenti where the National Disaster Plan is inadequate to deal with any given disaster (sect. 17). Part V of the Act provides for special powers during a state of public emergency whilst Part VI deals with miscellaneous matters such as compensation for any action taken under the National Disaster Plan (sect. 21) and utilisation of disaster assistance donations (sect. 23).
Subject: Environment gen.
Geographical_area: ASIA AND THE PACIFIC, Least Developed Countries, Micronesia, Oceania, Small Island Developing States, South Pacific

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 45 validating the Regulation on transportation of hazardous waste and mitigation of consequences of possible incidents.
Policy_Content: This Ministerial Decree establishes requirements for the transportation of hazardous substances by all means of transport on the national territory and sets basic provisions for organization, technical support and safety in the process of cargo-handling operations and transportation of hazardous substances. Owners of cargo of hazardous substances must inform in the written form 12 hours in advance local authorities on which territory shall be carried out transportation of hazardous substances of the route, time and type of cargo. Types of vehicles, storage and transportation conditions and labelling of cargo must comply with technical terms, conditions and standards. Hazardous substances shall be classified in accordance with risk category.
Subject: Environment gen.

Policy: Decree No. 21 of the Council of Ministers validating the Regulation on state control over environmental protection and management of natural resources.
Policy_Content: This Decree establishes that state control over environmental protection and management of natural resources shall have as its purpose to ensure compliance of competent state institutions, public and social enterprises and associations, natural persons and foreign legal and natural persons with the requirements of the national environmental legislation, environmental standards and other rules and regulations, and also performance of the arrangements for environmental protection and management of natural resources. It lists competent public bodies authorized to perform inspections with a view of verification of the presence of license for emissions, discharge of pollutants, waste disposal and management of natural resources.
Subject: Environment gen.

Policy: Forest Code (No.3852-XII of 1994).
Policy_Content: Forest relations in Ukraine are regulated by the present Forest Code, Law on environmental protection and other legislative acts of Ukraine. The purpose of Forest Code is the regulation of legal relations with the view of ensuring raising forest productivity, forest protection and afforestation, useful qualities, satisfaction of the needs of society in forest resources on the basis of their scientifically substantiated rational use. Forest land includes forest land on which forest plots are located and non-forest land occupied by agricultural land, waterbodies and swamps, buildings, communications, unproductive land, etc., which are allotted in the prescribed manner and used for forestry needs. Forest land shall not include land on which protective forest strips are located (art. 5). The right of private ownership of forests of citizens and legal entities of Ukraine arises from the date of state registration of ownership of land. Forests inherited by foreign nationals, stateless persons and foreign legal entities are subject to expropriation within one year. (art. 13). The right to forest management shall be exercised on condition of permanent and temporary forest management (art. 16). Specialized state forestry enterprises, other state enterprises, institutions and organizations in which specialized forestry subdivisions have been established shall be granted the right of permanent forest management with the allotment of forest located on public land (art. 17). The Act consists of 10 Sections, sub-divided into 23 Chapters that contain 103 articles. Section 1 (arts. 1-22) lays down general provisions. Section 2 (arts. 23-32) regards state management and state control in the sphere of safeguarding, protection, management and afforestation. Section 3 (arts. 33-47) regards organization of forest management. Section 4 (arts. 48-80) regards management of forest resources and the use of the plots of land pertaining to the stock of forest. Section 5  (arts. 81-84) regards afforestation and raising productivity of forests. Section 6 (arts. 85-88) regards safeguarding and protection of forests and forest service. Section 7 (arts. 89-92) regards fees for the use of forest resources and for the use of the plots of land pertaining to the stock of forest, subsidies for safeguarding, protection, rational use of forest and afforestation. Section 8 (arts. 93-96) regards forest management, state registration of the stock of forest and state forest cadastre. Section 9 (arts. 97-102) regards dispute settlement in the sphere of safeguarding, protection of forests and afforestation. It also establishes liability for the infringement of forest legislation. Section 10 (art. 103) regards international cooperation.
Subject: Forestry
Keyword: Framework law,Public forest,Private forest,Protection forest,Afforestation/reforestation,Forest service/forest officers,Forest management/forest conservation,Offences/penalties,Registration,Dispute settlement

Policy: Law 21 January 1994, n. 61 Conversion into Law, with amendments, of the Decree-Law 4 December 1993, n. 496, containing urgent provisions on the reorganization of environmental controls and establishment of the National Agency for the protection of the environment.
Policy_Content: This text here converts into Law the terms and provisions originally prescribed by the Italian Decree-Law 4 December 1993, n. 496, containing urgent provisions on the reorganization of environmental controls and establishment of the National Environmental Protection Agency. This Law establishes and regulates several issues as regards the National Environmental Protection Agency, Regional and Provincial Environmental Agencies. These shall be established by the Regions, as local Agencies with technical and scientific competencies, within their geographical areas, in environmental conservation matters, with obligation of general national coordination and cooperation and data exchange.

Policy: Regional Law on the protection of public health (1994).
Policy_Content: Protection of public health is aimed at the conservation and strengthening public health, maintenance of good health and active life that are guaranteed by the state and ensured by the sanitary, hygienic and anti-epidemic arrangements. Regional executive bodies have the following competence in the sphere of the protection of public health: 1. elaboration and realization of regional programs; 2. nature management, environmental protection, ensuring ecological safety in relation to public health; 3. ensuring sanitary and epidemiological well-being of the population and regional state sanitary and epidemiological survey. Local self-government has the following competence: 1.environmental protection and ensuring ecological safety, carrying out quarantine arrangements, liquidation of the consequences of disasters, ensuring sanitary and epidemiological well-being of the population, exposure of unfavourable factors to public health, information of the population of them and carrying out arrangements for their removal. The document consists of XII Secs. Section I lays down general provisions. Section II regards organization of protection of public health. Section III establishes the rights of citizens. Section IV establishes the rights of some groups of the population. Section V regards medical activity in the field of family planning. Section VII regards ensuring medical assistance. Section VIII regards provision facilities in sanatoria and health resorts. Section IX regards medical expertise. Section X establishes the rights and social welfare of medical and pharmaceutical personnel. Section XI establishes liability for the observance of the rights of citizens in the sphere of the protection of public health. Section XII regards international cooperation.
Subject: Environment gen., Food & nutrition
Keyword: Education,Access-to-information,Monitoring,Disasters,Environmental standards,Liability/compensation,Early warning system/emergency intervention system,Hygiene/sanitary procedures,Food quality control/food safety

Policy: Timber Regulations, 1993 (SOR/94-118).
Policy_Content: Regulations respecting the cutting and removal of timber. These Regulations apply in respect of the cutting and removal of timber on lands referred to in section 5 of the Forestry Act. No person, except if he is an employee of the Government of Canada, shall cut and remove timber in a forest area except under the authority of a permit issued by a forestry officer pursuant to section 7 of the Act or an agreement entered into with the Minister under section 14. Where the forestry officer issueing the permit includes terms or conditions in a permit or gives instructions for the protection of the forest area, those conditions or instructions shall be to encourage regeneration and reforestation, to avoid damage to vegetation or to the timber that is not covered by the permit, and to avoid damage to the cutting and removal site and any animal habitats (reg. 8). Where a permit holder cuts and removes timber in excess of the amount set out in the permit, the permit holder shall pay to the Receiver General fees calculated by a forestry officer pursuant to section 6. The Minister may, after making a public call for tenders, enter into an agreement for the cutting and removal of timber in a forest area with individuals or corporations.
Subject: Forestry
Keyword: Forest management/forest conservation,Forestry protection measures,Timber extraction/logging,Authorization/permit

Policy: Loi nº 94/01 portant régime des forêts, de la faune et de la pêche.
Policy_Content: La présente loi abroge et remplace sa devancière, adoptée le 27 novembre 1981, qui avait le même objet, à savoir le régime juridique des forêts, de la faune et de la pêche. Il s'agit d'une loi dont les dispositions de base doivent être complétées par une série de textes réglementaires d'application. La loi est fondée sur une approche de gestion intégrée et durable, alliant la conservation et l'utilisation soutenues des ressources et des écosystèmes. Elle se compose des sept titres suivants: (I) dispositions générales; (II) protection de la nature et de la biodiversité ; (III) forêts; (IV) faune; (V) pêche; (VI) répression des infractions ; (VII) dispositions diverses et finales. Le titre II interdit en principe les feux de brousse, soumet le défrichement d'une forêt à son déclassement, subordonne à étude d'impact sur l'environnement les projets de développement susceptibles de perturber le milieu naturel, etc. Il prévoit en outre les modalités de mise en défens ou de classement en aires protégées des zones forestières dont le maintien est nécessaire pour assurer la conservation des sols ou de la biodiversité, la régulation du régime hydrique, etc. Les ressources génétiques du patrimoine national appartiennent à l'Etat et leur utilisation à des fins lucratives donne lieu au paiement de royalties. Le titre III distingue deux grandes catégories de forêts: (i) les forêts permanentes, ou classées, qui sont constituées par les terres définitivement affectées à la forêt et/ou à l'habitat de la faune; et (ii) les forêts non permanentes, ou non classées, qui sont susceptibles d'être affectées à des utilisations autres que forestières. Les forêts permanentes doivent couvrir au moins 30 pour cent du territoire national. Les forêts permanentes se subdivisent elles-mêmes en forêts domaniales et forêts communales. Quant aux forêts non permanentes, elles comprennent trois catégories distinctes de forêts, à savoir: (i) les forêts du domaine national, dont les produits appartiennent en principe à l'Etat et où les droits d'usage peuvent être normalement exercés; (ii) les forêts communautaires, catégorie nouvelle non définie, dont il est cependant précisé que les produits de leur exploitation appartiennent entièrement aux communautés villageoises concernées; (iii) les forêts des particuliers. L'exploitation forestière, qui est subordonnée à un inventaire préalable de la forêt concernée, ne peut être pratiquée que par les personnes physiques ou morales ayant été formellement agréées. Les modalités d'exploitation diffèrent en fonction des catégories de forêts. L'aménagement des forêts est conçu comme englobant les opérations d'inventaire, de reboisement, de régénération, d'exploitation soutenue et de réalisation d'infrastructures. Le financement de ces activités est assuré par le Fonds spécial de développement forestier. Les espèces animales sauvages sont réparties en trois classes: A, intégralement protégée, B et C, partiellement protégées et dont l'exploitation est réglementée. Les procédés et les engins de chasse susceptibles de nuire à la faune sont en principe prohibés. Mise à part la chasse traditionnelle, qui est autorisée sur toute l'étendue du territoire sauf dans les forêts domaniales, tout acte de chasse est subordonné à l'obtention d'un permis ou d'une licence et au paiement des droits et des taxes correspondants. Les ranches de gibier appartiennent à l'Etat, leur gestion peut se faire en régie directe ou en affermage par des organismes spécialisés. Le titre V relatif à la pêche distingue sept moyens d'obtention des ressources halieutiques: la pêche industrielle, la pêche semi-industrielle, la pêche traditionnelle ou artisanale, la pêche sportive, la pêche scientifique, la mariculture et la pisciculture. Sur le plan des principes, le droit de pêche appartient à l'Etat, que ce soit dans le domaine maritime ou dans le domaine fluvial. L'exploitation industrielle des produits halieutiques est subordonnée à l'obtention préalable d'un agrément. Une licence est nécessaire pour l'exercice de la pêche industrielle, tandis que les autres formes de pêche, à l'exception de celle artisanale, requièrent un permis. La délivrance et le renouvellement des licences et des permis donnent lieu à la perception d'une taxe d'exploitation. Des ressources halieutiques, des restrictions peuvent être apportées à la pêche, par décret, en vue d'assurer la protection de la faune et des milieux aquatiques et, également, afin de maintenir la production à un niveau acceptable. L'administration compétente peut interdire la pêche de certaines espèces protégées et fixer des zones ou des secteurs dans lesquels la pêche ne peut être pratiquée. Ces mesures sont complétées par des dispositions relatives à la gestion des installations aquacoles et des établissements de pêche, ainsi qu'à l'inspection sanitaire, au contrôle, au conditionnement et au transport des produits de la pêche. Le titre VI, enfin, traite de la répression des infractions, dont la recherche et la constatation incombent aux agents assermentés des administrations chargées de ces secteurs. Les infractions peuvent en général donner lieu à transaction. Faute de celle-ci, les actions sont engagées contre les accusés devant les tribunaux ordinaires. Les sanctions pénales sont principalement de deux ordres: pécuniaires et/ou privatives de liberté.
Subject: Fisheries, Forestry, Wild species & ecosystems
Keyword: Marine fisheries,Basic legislation,Fishery management and conservation,Inland fisheries,Artisanal fishing,Governance,Aquaculture,Offences/penalties,Forestry protection measures,Forest management/forest conservation,Biodiversity,Management/conservation,Wild fauna,Wild flora,Hunting/capture,Hunting rights,Ranching/captive breeding

Policy: Ley Nº 16.466 - Declara de interés general la protección del medio ambiente contra cualquier tipo de depredación, destrucción o contaminación.
Policy_Content: La Ley, que consta de 18 artículos, declara de interés general y nacional la protección del medio ambiente, la prevención del impacto ambiental negativo y, en su caso, la recomposición del medio ambiente dañado por actividades humanas (art. 1º). Establece que, sin perjuicio de las sanciones administrativas y penales, quien provoque destrucción del medio ambiente será civilmente responsable de todos los perjuicios que ocasione, debiendo hacerse cargo además, si materialmente ello fuere posible, de las acciones conducentes a su recomposición (art. 4º). La presente Ley dispone que quedan sometidas a la realización previa de un estudio de impacto ambiental diversas actividades, construcciones y obras públicas o privadas (art. 6º).
Subject: Environment gen.
Keyword: Pollution control,Ecosystem preservation,EIA,Legal proceedings/administrative proceedings,Environmental standards,Soil conservation/soil improvement

Policy: Loi nº 002/94/ADP portant Code de l'environnement au BurkinaFaso.
Policy_Content: Cette loi portant Code de l'environnement se compose de cinq titres traitant successivement: (i) des définitions et du champ d'application; (ii) de la protection de l'environnement (9 chapitres consacrés à l'étude d'impact; aux établissements dangereux, insalubres et incommodes; aux déchets urbains et industriels; aux produits phytosanitaires, antiparasitaires et fertilisants; aux pollutions atmosphériques; à la protection des espaces, des espèces, des sites et des monuments); (iii) des institutions de protection et de gestion de l'environnement; (iv) des dispositions diverses; et (v) des dispositions finales.

Policy: Patent Law (No. I-372 of 1994).
Policy_Content: This Law shall legitimise inventions as objects of industrial property, regulate the rights and duties of legal and natural persons with respect to inventions, provide legal protection thereof. The form of protection of inventions shall be a patent granted by the State Patent Bureau in the procedure established by this Law (art. 1). Patents shall be available for any inventions in all fields of technology, provided that they are new, involve an inventive step and are capable of industrial application. Patents shall not be granted for: 1) methods for treatment of the human or animal body by surgery or therapy, and diagnostic and prophylactic methods practised on the human or animal body. This provision shall not apply if an object of invention is equipment or materials utilised for such methods; 2) plant or animal varieties or essentially biological processes for the production of plants or animals. This provision shall not apply to microbiological processes for the production of plants or animals or the products thereof (art. 2). An invention shall be considered industrially applicable if it can be made or used in industry, agriculture, health protection and other spheres (art. 5). A patent application shall contain: 1) a request for the grant of a patent; 2) a description of the invention; 3) one or more claims; 4) drawings if necessary for the understanding of the essence of the invention; 5) an abstract; 6) a document confirming payment of the fee; 7) a document confirming the right to file a patent application (provided it is filed not by inventor himself) and the declaration regarding inventorship of the invention (art. 11). The State Patent Bureau shall keep the Register of Patents of the Republic of Lithuania. On the register patents shall be assigned a serial number in the order of their grant (art. 23). A supplementary protection certificate may be granted to a patent owner or his successor in title for a period not exceeding five years, if legal protection is conferred to: 1) active substances of a plant protection product (art. 271 ).  The Law consists of 12 Sections composed of 62 articles.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development, Cultivated plants
Geographical_area: Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries, Northern Europe
Entry into force notes: The Law enters into force on 1 February 1994.

Policy: Regional Act No. 2 laying down provisions for the consolidation and the development of mountain agriculture and for the protection and improvement of mountain areas.
Policy_Content: This Regional Act is aimed at supporting and encouraging the economic and social development of agriculture in mountain areas. The Region shall endeavour to reduce and remove social, economic and infrastructure imbalance between mountain areas and any other territory than mountain areas. The Regional Act is divided into five Titles. The provisions shall apply to territories classified as mountain areas in accordance with Regional Act No. 19 of 3 July 1992.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development, Forestry
Geographical_area: Alps, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries, Mediterranean, Southern Europe

Policy: Ley Agrícola y Forestal para el Estado de Tamaulipas.
Policy_Content: La presente Ley establece las bases para lograr un desarrollo sustentable de las actividades agrícolas y forestales, con el propósito de incrementar su eficiencia, productividad y competitividad mediante el mejoramiento de la relación con los elementos naturales, la aplicación de la tecnología, el desarrollo de la investigación y la consideración de las condiciones socioeconómicas de los productores. Asimismo la Ley busca promover la participación de los productores en el proceso agrícola y forestal. La Ley se compone de los siguientes Títulos: I) Del objeto y materia de esta Ley; II) De la producción agrícola y forestal; III) De la protección fitosanitaria; IV) De la comercialización agrícola y forestal; V) De la inspección y sanciones.

Policy: Government Decision on allocation of forest land to organizations, households, and individuals for long-term forestry purposes (No. 02/CP).
Policy_Content: According to the provisions of this Decision, the following forest land shall be allocated to organizations, households and individuals: (a) land which has natural or planted forest; (b) land which does not have forest but should be afforested through planting, assisted natural regeneration, or protection of the vegetation. The allocation of forest land shall be carried out taking into account: (a) the availability of forest land in different localities; and (b) the management and investment policies and projects to be approved by the competent State authorities.

Policy: Resource Management Regulations.
Policy_Content: These Regulations, promulgated and issued by the Development Review Commission pursuant to Title 7, Chapter 4 of the Kosrae Code, provide for environmental impact assessment procedures so as to assist the general public and government officials to make decisions with the understanding of the environmental consequences of their decisions, and take actions consistent with the goal of protecting, restoring, and enhancing the environment. In addition, these Regulations are intended to: (a) integrate the EIA process into the early planning of projects to insure timely consideration of environmental factors in order to avoid delays; and (b) identify at an early stage the significant environmental issues requiring further study, defining the scope of the Environmental Impact Statement. The Regulations shall apply to all development projects as defined in paragraph 1.3. A Development Review Permit shall be required for development projects that fall within the parameters of section 7.402 of Title 7 of the Kosrae Code or for development projects satisfying criteria as specified by these Regulations. The Regulations also provide with respect to earthmoving activities within Kosrae State, which shall be conducted in accordance with these Regulations and in such a way as to prevent accelerated erosion and accelerated sedimentation.
Subject: Environment gen.
Keyword: Pollution control,EIA,Environmental planning,Erosion,Soil conservation/soil improvement,Soil pollution/quality,Soil rehabilitation,Authorization/permit,Legal proceedings/administrative proceedings,Offences/penalties

The text consists of 19 articles divided into 5 Parts as follows: General provisions (1); Hunting association (2); Hunting measures (3); Hunting supervision (4); Final provision (5).

Policy: Decreto Nº 1/94 - Crea el Ministerio del Ambiente y los Recursos Naturales.
Policy_Content: El presente Decreto, que consta de 8 artículos, crea el Ministerio del Ambiente y los Recursos Naturales (MARENA), que coordinará y dirigirá la política ambiental del Estado y promoverá el aprovechamiento sostenible de los recursos naturales de la nación (art. 1º). Entre sus atribuciones, tendrá: a) participar en la elaboración de planes, programas y proyectos de protección al ambiente y los recursos naturales; b) formular, evaluar, actualizar y coordinar la ejecución de la estrategia de ordenamiento ambiental del territorio e impulsar el plan de acción forestal; c) organizar y coordinar el sistema nacional de información y vigilancia ambiental; d) administrar y manejar las áreas protegidas, de reserva y parques nacionales; e) proponer la promulgación, revisión y estandarización de las normas de calidad ambiental; f) apoyar en la prevención y control de desastres y emergencias ambientales (art. 2º).

Policy: Environmental Impact Assessment Regulations 1994.
Policy_Content: These Regulations, promulgated by the Republic of the Marshall Islands Environmental Protection Authority, implement Part IV of the National Environmental Protection Act 1984 and section 11 of the Coast Conservation Act 1988 by establishing standard procedures for the preparation and evaluation of an environmental impact assessment for proposed public and private development activities that may affect the quality of the environment of the Republic. The Regulations establish uniform standards under two Acts so that environmental scrutiny of proposed development activities may be streamlined and simplified.
Subject: Environment gen.
Geographical_area: Micronesia, Oceania, South Pacific

Policy: Grain Management Act.
Policy_Content: This Act provides for the stabilization of the national economy by means of ensuring a smooth circulation of the supply and demand of grain i.e. rice, barley, wheat, oats, rye, etc., and maintaining proper prices through efficient management. The Minister of Agriculture and Forestry shall establish the annual plan for the supply and demand of the grain under government management. The Minister of Agriculture and Forestry may purchase grain from, or make advance payments to producers or owners as prescribed by the Presidential Decree, so as to control the supply and demand and to maintain proper prices (arts. 4 and 5). Article 9 specifies the uses for which the Minister of Agriculture and Forestry may sell the grain under government management. Permission of importation of rice, etc. and grain shall be obtained by the Minister of Agriculture and Forestry (art. 12) who shall also manage these products as described in article 13. Grain processing businesses need to be registered and report to the head of Si/Gun/Gu. In order to control the supply and demand of grain and establish the distributive order of grain, the Minister may order grain dealers to take measures listed in article 20. The Deliberation Committee on Grain Policies shall be installed in the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry as an advisory committee to treat such matters as the demand and supply of grain and the stabilization of prices. The remaining part of the Act contains supplementary and penal provisions.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development, Food & nutrition
Geographical_area: Asia, ASIA AND THE PACIFIC, East Asian Seas, Eastern Asia, North Pacific, North-West Pacific

Policy: Act No. 37 on the environmental protection of riveraine and lacustrine areas belonging to the public domain, 1994.
Policy_Content: With a view to effecting the environmental protection of the bed of rivers and lakes, which dry up and become exposed as a result of a natural or man-made change in the former course of the river or surface of the lake, the statute reverses the rules governing ownership of newly-exposed river or lake beds (called riveraine and lacustrine "appurtenances"), which henceforth shall accrue to the State in lieu of the owners of riparian or coastal land. As a result, uses of such areas come within the scope of authority of pre-existing provincial commissions especially created to manage the riveraine and lacustrine "appurtenances" belonging to the public domain. In addition, the Act has shifted the statutory preference for the use of such lands by the owners of riparian or coastal land for their own private purposes to the local governments for purposes of creating natural parks or reserves.
Subject: Land & soil, Water
Keyword: Land tenure,Bed,Bank,Public land,Transfer,Ownership,Pollution control,Freshwater quality/freshwater pollution,Inland waters

Policy: Law SEMAS No. 5.793 approving the Mining and Water policy of the State of Pará, its objectives, guidelines and instruments.
Policy_Content: This Law approves the Mining and Water Policy of the State of Pará. The Policy will be implemented in accordance with the following principles: respect for the physical environment and the preservation and optimization of the use of natural resources, aiming at the quality of life of the population; maximize the positive effects generated by the exploitation of mineral and water resources of the State, in order to: stimulate the generation of investments, jobs and the expansion of economic activity to serve the local market; create integrated programmes; promote development activities and technological diffusion of the mineral and water sectors; define mineral exploration strategies that contemplate various productive sectors, including mining activities; support and assist the organization, implementation and operation of a mining, cooperative activity, seeking, primarily, to promote better conditions for the exploration and transformation of mineral resources, with access to new technologies in the sector; support and promote the exploitation of the potential of hydro-power generation; manage and co-ordinate surface and groundwater, respecting natural systems as an integral part of the hydro-logical cycle; protection of the right of its population to reach an adequate well-being, through an integrated process of development in a territorial and harmonious way.
Subject: Mineral resources, Water

Acquisition and land or freehold or leasehold title by non-Bahamians requires a permit of the Secretary of the Board and shall also be registered in accordance with this Act. Policy: Native Title (Tribunal) Regulations 1993.
Policy_Content: These Regulations provide for: (a) the form in which applications made under subsection 61[2] of the Act are to be made, and (b) the servicing of documents in relation with legal proceedings. An application under subsection 61[2] is an application for the determination of native title made to the Registrar of the National Native Title Tribunal. They are amended by giving new rules for the exemption of fees for the granting of applications and the inspection of Registers. Regulation 17 which provides for the calculation of fees is replaced by a new regulation. The fee for an application is not payable if the person liable to pay the fee makes an application under section 35 of the Native Title Act for a determination in relation to a future act in the circumstances that a person if a Government part, the person previously made an application under section 35 and a few other circumstances. Minor amendments are made to section 17 and form 1 contained in Schedule 1 (application for a determination of native title).(17 regulations and 2 Schedules containing forms and a list of fees for witnesses)

Policy: Law No. LA-91 “On consumer cooperation”.
Policy_Content: This Law establishes organizational and legal bases of consumer cooperatives, the procedure and conditions for the establishment and operation of consumer cooperatives and their associations, as well as the principles of their relations with state bodies. Consumer cooperative shall be intended a voluntary association of shareholders meeting the demand of members for commodities and services, presenting their interests and implementing them for the benefit of shareholders. Consumer cooperative does not pursue the purpose of gaining profit as the profits shall be used only for the achievement of its statutory goals. Organizational forms of consumer cooperatives shall be consumer enterprises, consumers and associations of consumer cooperatives. Consumer cooperatives, in accordance with statutory goals thereof, shall be authorized to perform trade, vending, production, processing, manufacturing, external trade and other activities envisaged by the legislation. Consumer cooperative is a voluntary association composed of not less than 30 members (shareholders), formed on their monetary and other material investments and holding the status of legal entity. The state shall support consumer cooperatives and their economic independence. Consumer cooperatives, consumer enterprises and associations thereof shall be subject to mandatory state registration. Property of consumer cooperatives shall be protected by the state.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development, Food & nutrition
Keyword: Cooperative/producer organization,Consumer protection,Public private partnership (PPP),Inspection,Internal trade,International trade,Processing/handling,Vending,Food quality control/food safety
Geographical_area: Asia, CIS (Commonwealth of Independent States), EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, Landlocked Developing Countries, Western Asia
Entry into force notes: This Law enters into force on 30 April 1994.

Policy: Ministerial Decree No. 13/1994 specifying some details of agricultural land resources protection.
Policy_Content: The agricultural land resources protection authorities may impose a change in the cultivation of agricultural land in cases where the land management with the present plant species leads to: a) the danger of erosion of the land on the property in question and on surrounding properties; b) a detriment to the purity and quality of water  in water courses and water reservoirs; c) a danger to surface or underground sources of potable water, natural medicinal waters and sources of natural mineral table waters; d) failure to comply with rights and obligations with regard to the protection of nature and the landscape; e) damage to surrounding properties or to the favourable physical, biological and chemical properties of the soil; f) danger to the food chain. In order to ensure the protection of agricultural land resources, the preparation of land use planning documentation and basic land use planning documents should be based on: a) the organization of the agricultural land resources in the territory, the hydrological and run-off conditions and the network of special-purpose agricultural roads; b) a plan for terrain modifications and delimitation of the currently built-up areas in the given municipality; c) the plant culture (type of property) of the agricultural land on the basis of assignment to evaluated ecological land units; d) the existence of non-agricultural land required to support agricultural production and fish ponds for fish farming or waterfowl; e) the existence of agricultural land on which investments have been made into the soil for the purpose of increasing fertility, e.g. amelioration and irrigation facilities.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development
Geographical_area: Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries

Policy: Act establishing the Agency for Restructuring and Modernizing Agriculture.
Policy_Content: The Act, which is composed of fifteen paragraphs, establishes the Agency for Restructuring and Modernizing Agriculture, located in Warsaw. The Agency supports the following activities: investments on agriculture, food processing and services concerning agriculture; undertakings in order to start, increase or resume agricultural production; improvement of agrarian structures, particularly creation or expansion of family farms; undertakings creating new working places for the country citizens; development of technical and production infrastructure of small cities, villages and agriculture; undertakings concerning the improvement of professional qualification of country citizens; restructuring of research and development units supporting agriculture and food management; creation and development of agricultural insurance associations; development of information infrastructure of cooperative banks; creation and development of agricultural producers groups and their associations; undertakings concerning production and processing of agricultural raw materials in order to produce biocomponents for liquid fuel production; implementation of other tasks of the national policy concerning agriculture and food processing; high school education of country citizens; development of ecological education and education concerning ecology.
Subject: Agricultural & rural development
Geographical_area: Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, European Union Countries
Entry into force notes: The Act enters into force 14 days after its publication in the Journal of Laws.

Policy: Order No. 347 of the Federal Forest Service validating the Regulation on resin boxing in the forests of the Russian Federation.
Policy_Content: This Order regulates resin boxing in the national forests and it shall be binding on all forest managers that collect resin and on all forest owners. Areas of public forest used to collect and box resin shall be deemed areas of compulsory resin boxing. Each area shall be classified as one of three categories according to resin output. Mature and overly mature pinaceous trees in areas of compulsory resin boxing shall have resin boxed before felling. Forest plantations in areas in which main use felling is not scheduled for the next 10 to15 years shall not be subject to resin boxing. The transfer of forest plantations for resin boxing without approved plans of timber extraction and resin boxing shall be prohibited. Resin boxing shall be authorized exclusively in accordance with felling contracts, which must be concluded by 1 January of each year.
Subject: Forestry
Geographical_area: Arctic, ASIA AND THE PACIFIC, Black Sea, Caspian Sea, CIS (Commonwealth of Independent States), Eastern Europe, Europe, EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA, North Pacific, North-West Pacific

Policy_Content: These Regulations concern procedures of appeal with the Environment Adjudication Tribunal established under the Environment Protection Act. (7 regulations completed by 2 Schedules: Notice of appeal under section 4692) of the Environment Protection Act 1991 against, direction, order, or notice referred to in section 46(1) of the Act; Declaration of fidelity and secrecy)
